Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: A critical bearing is screeching loudly and threatening an immediate breakdown.
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story: The shrill screech of the bearing echoed through the factory, vibrating up my arms as I pressed my hand to the machine’s side. I knew what that sound meant—if I didn’t get it fixed now, the whole line could grind to a halt, costing hours of production and risking my reputation as the go-to repairer. My supervisor’s words from this morning rang in my ears: “We can’t afford any downtime today. Stay sharp.” I reached for my toolkit, but my phone buzzed with a reminder: “Polls close at 8 PM. Don’t forget your ID.” I glanced at the clock—barely enough time to make it across town, and I’d have to dig my ID out of my locker, all the way at the other end of the plant. My chest tightened. I’d promised myself I’d vote this year, that I wouldn’t let work swallow up my civic duty. But the machine’s wail grew louder, and I could almost feel the eyes of my coworkers and boss on me, expecting me to save the day. I stood frozen, torn between the screeching metal and the weight of my own promise.
